MASHAV Report.Guiding Principles: Activities based on capacity building, technical assistance, and the transferring of Israeli knowhow, innovation, technologies and expertise Focus in sectors in which Israel has accumulated expertise and a comparative advantage MASHAV believes that development cooperation should and can be used to forge bonds of peaceful cooperation between Israel and its neighbors Demand-driven programming and active consultation with local partners Pursuing multi-stakeholder partnerships with the civil society and private sector to achieve the SDGs Holistic, inclusive and integrative approach to development Engaging in Guided by bilateral, trilateral and multilateral development cooperation creating synergies between complimentary strengths universal principles for the achievement of the 2030 Agenda for Sustainable Development 2 Guiding Principles Foreword by the Head OF 2024 was another challenging year for us in Israel, both personally and professionally. The ongoing war, the multiple threats – south, north, and east of the country, the challenges facing shattered families, destroyed communities, hundreds of thousands of internally displaced people, and most of all – the enormous loss, the pain and the fear regarding the fate of the Israeli hostages in Gaza, kept us away from any sense of closure and introduced difficult choices. These strained circumstances shaped our lives, and their shadows are reflected in every aspect, without exception. Yet, as we constantly engage in further galvanizing our resilience, despite all complexities, including budget constraints, MASHAV continues its quest, promoting sustainable development and implementing training and capacity-building programs in collaboration with our partners. The bright moments during this year were the release days of hostages, who had spent long months, some more than a year and a few months, in captivity, held by Hamas and Islamic Jihad's terrorists in Gaza (76 hostages are still held in captivity as I write these paragraphs). Among those released were agricultural and development experts who had worked and partnered closely with MASHAV for decades. One of the agronomists was held hostage for 482 (!) days. We hope they will continue their invaluable work in the future, benefiting the world. Dozens of people are still held in Gaza; among them are two foreign agriculture students who were kidnapped during the October 7 massacre from southern Israel while participating in the Internship in Agriculture Program. We pray for the immediate and safe release of all the hostages who remain in captivity. As the war persisted throughout 2024, MASHAV's training centers continued to offer assistance to the displaced communities. Due to the unstable security situation and massive rocket shelling, particularly in northern Israel, some training sessions had to be conducted online. However, others were held in person in Israel. We were happy to welcome our partners for international capacity-building courses here and kept nourishing our investment in human capital. We sent experts on consulting and training missions abroad and continued to collaborate with numerous local and international partners. We continued to develop existing and new centers of excellence in agriculture and emergency medicine, supervised projects established by MASHAV together with local partners in previous years, and supported innovative initiatives suggested and implemented by our alumni around the globe. The hardships faced at home, during 2024, did not reduce our commitment to provide humanitarian assistance to countries and communities facing natural and manmade disasters, such as fires, droughts, earthquakes, and floods, as well as the continued support of our partners in Ukraine, providing assistance and, most importantly, tailor- made capacity-building programs on trauma care, community resilience, and more, sharing our own experiences. At MASHAV, we remain committed to promoting our goals, which are aligned with the Global Agenda 2030. This commitment is reflected in the 2024 MASHAV Activity Report, which I am honored to present to you – wishing us all long-lasting peace. Ambassador Eynat Shlein Head of MASHAV Deputy Director General, Ministry of Foreign Affairs
MASHAV Report.About MASHAV: Israel’s Agency for International Development Cooperation Our Mission To lead Israel's efforts in empowering individuals and communities in need by sharing tools and expertise to achieve sustainable development and transformation within their own societies. History MASHAV was established in 1958 following the vision of then Foreign Minister Golda Meir and Prime Minister David Ben Gurion to assist fellow nations overcome development challenges by sharing knowhow and technologies, which provided the basis of Israel’s own development. About us MASHAV – Israel’s Agency for International Development Cooperation at Israel’s Ministry of Foreign Affairs is responsible for the design, coordination and implementation of the State of Israel’s development cooperation programs and humanitarian assistance efforts. By placing people at the heart of development, we focus our development activities on human capacity building and on the ‘training of trainers’ approach, sharing with other countries Israel’s own development experience and expertise as well as innovative technologies and tested methodologies. In alignment with the 2030 Sustainable Development Agenda, and as a member of the family of nations, the State of Israel through MASHAV, shares the global responsibility of striving to overcome development challenges and contributing to the fight against poverty, while leaving no-one behind. 4 About MASHAV How We Work MASHAV's training program is comprised of technical assistance and human capacity building based on a demand-driven approach and in accordance with the needs and requests of partner countries. MASHAV’s professional activities take place both in Israel and in partner countries. In Israel: MASHAV conducts its extensive capacity- building program in Israel through professional affiliated leading institutes, and through its core specialized training and consultancy centers: • Professional training programs • International conferences • Thematic delegations In Partner Countries: • On-the-spot training programs • Short and long-term expert consultancies • Establishment of Centers of Excellence in Agriculture for professional training Development COOperation MASHAV emphasizes the importance of creating effective partnerships for development and of implementing cooperative projects both in Israel and abroad with a wide range of partners with each side contributing its strengths and unique experience and expertise. • Active dialogues for development with donor countries and sister agencies • Signing bi- and trilateral development cooperation agreements with partner countries • Multilateral cooperation About MASHAV 5
MASHAV Report.Priority Sectors: In line with the United Nations 2030 Agenda's sustainable development goals, OECD recommendations and good practice of DAC members MASHAV concentrates and limits the number of sectors in which it operates, focusing its activities on areas in which Israel has a comparative advantage and accumulated expertise: FOOD Security, Agriculture and Climate Change MASHAV’s capacity building programs in the area of Food Security, Agriculture and Climate Change aim to harness the full potential of farmers, both men and women, with the goal of attaining the 2030 Agenda Sustainable Development Goal 2: To end hunger, achieve food security and improved nutrition and promote sustainable agriculture. Based on Israel's own agricultural and rural development experience to develop the agro and rural sectors under semi-arid and arid climatic conditions, MASHAV's activities include water management and irrigation; livestock production; environment and climate change; introduction of applied research and innovative approaches, agro-technologies and agricultural extension. Education FOr All In alignment with Goal 4, MASHAV shares the unique knowledge accumulated in Israel in addressing the direct challenge of achieving inclusive and quality education for all. Activities range from early childhood education to adult education, special education and programs for at-risk youth as well as topics such as innovation and entrepreneurship for the educational system, ICT in education, capacity building for educators and school staff through civic awareness based on democratic principles. Medicine and Public Health MASHAV, in alignment with Goal 3, is committed to develop and implement inclusive and resilient health-related programs in order to provide equitable access to quality health services for all. Based on the experience accumulated in Israel, MASHAV designs and implements professional activities characterized by a long-term approach, focusing on capacity building and community resilience, urgent care medicine, trauma care and a mass-casualty incidents. Research and Development In alignment with the 2030 Agenda, MASHAV believes that groundbreaking innovations and technologies are critical to enhancing agricultural productivity and reducing poverty, and should be made accessible to all. 6 Priority Sectors Community Development Civil society can serve as a catalyst for political, social and economic transformation and play a critical role in the achievement of the SDGs. It often represents the interests and needs of various sectors and echelons of society, including the most marginalized and disenfranchised communities. Resilient communities and civil societies also promote good governance, while demanding transparency of government institutions and policies, which strengthen community services, and advance adherence to the rule of law and universal human rights principles. MASHAV’s activities in community development present a unique blend of capacity building, preparedness and emergency management, and encouragement of collaborate action by strengthening the civil society, with gender mainstreaming and the promotion of gender equality as cross cutting issues. Innovation and Entrepreneurship In alignment with the 2030 Agenda, MASHAV promotes innovating entrepreneurship as a means of advancing growth and prosperity addressing entrepreneurship as a critical development tool and a driver of job creation, economic growth, gender equality and the realization of social gains. MASHAV professional capacity building programs in the field present both the governmental and the non-governmental frameworks that promote Innovation and Entrepreneurship. Gender Equality and Women's Empowerment Women have a critical role to play in all of the Agenda 2030 as is especially represented in Goal 5. MASHAV considers the empowerment of women as a critical and central component of its development policy, relating to gender equality not only as a fundamental human right, but also as a necessary foundation for a peaceful, prosperous and sustainable world. MASHAV’s programs in the field focus on strengthening entrepreneurial skills and innovation through capacity building and the transfer of individual and community leadership skills and strategies related to women's economic empowerment, including the empowerment of rural women by ways of agricultural entrepreneurship, to contribute to income generation and employment. Rural and Urban Development The goal of eradicating poverty is achieved through the promotion of social-economic rural and urban development, while viewing the region as the basic unit for development and planning. MASHAV’s programs include professional training in the areas of regional and local competitivity; local economic development and strategies for poverty reduction; income generation activities in rural areas; strategic planning for local development; urban rehabilitation projects; development of sustainable rural tourism. Humanitarian Aid As an active member of the international aid community, MASHAV is the body responsible for coordinating the State of Israel’s official humanitarian assistance program. Drawing on Israel’s vast experience in crisis response and field medicine, we rapidly organize and dispatch much needed supplies, medicines and urgent medical assistance in response to appeals from senior sources in the international community as well as to direct requests from affected countries. Along the years, Israel has sent humanitarian relief and assistance to more than 140 countries, saving numerous numbers of lives. Priority Sectors 7
MASHAV Report.Highlights: Since its establishment in 1958, MASHAV has been active in 140 countries worldwide, directly training more than 350,000 men and women in a wide variety of fields. MASHAV believes that history calls upon us all to join hands and bring change, hope, and opportunity to every human being. This has been, and continues to be, the backbone of the State of Israel’s international development cooperation. We strongly believe that the Sustainable Development Goals and Global Agenda 2030 continue to be the catalyst for creating fruitful development cooperation partnerships for the benefit of those who need it most. In 2024, Israel faced a wartime reality that inevitably limited some activities within the country. Nevertheless, we remained steadfast in our mission, continuing our efforts abroad at full force while maintaining as much activity in Israel as conditions allowed. The following are highlights of MASHAV’s 2024 development cooperation activities in Israel and worldwide. 8 Highlights Special activities in Israel The Internship in Agriculture Administration Collaboration with Civil SOCiety FOr International Development Following its establishment in December 2020, the Internship in Agriculture Administration commenced operations to oversee and regulate the Internship in Agriculture Program. The program aims to build agricultural capacity among interns from developing nations in Africa, Asia, and Oceania by providing practical and theoretical training in modern agriculture. It fosters an entrepreneurial mindset and introduces innovative methods and knowledge to approximately 4,000 international students or recent graduates of agricultural studies, equipping them with a modern toolbox. The 11-month internship is facilitated by five training centers across Israel, offering one day of weekly theoretical studies and five days of hands- on paid training with Israeli farmers who mentor the interns. Upon returning home, graduates leverage their acquired knowledge and accumulated savings to establish agricultural enterprises, strengthening food security and contributing to their local and national economies. Despite the war and its disruptions, the program has persevered. The 2023-24 cohort consists of 3,204 interns from 20 African and Asian countries who continued to gain knowledge and hands-on experience in Israel. In 2024, as in previous years, MASHAV conducted a periodic meeting with the Society for International Development (SID) and its member organizations to share updates on ongoing activities. This meeting addressed, among other topics, the special efforts being made to support local Israeli communities affected by the ongoing war. Additionally, the participants explored opportunities for further cooperation. In collaboration with SID, MASHAV also arranged meetings with designated ambassadors to facilitate mutual updates and coordinate ongoing activities in the countries to which the ambassadors were assigned. Additionally, SID Israel was invited by MASHAV as every year to participate in MASHAV’s presentation at the Ministry of Foreign Affairs’ National Cadet Course, highlighting the importance of cooperation with civil society organizations acting in the area of international development and humanitarian aid. GlOCal – International Development MASHAV’s Director of Planning, Evaluation, and Partnerships congratulated the graduates of the Glocal interdisciplinary Master’s program at the Hebrew University of Jerusalem. As in previous years, the Head of the Program, along with one of the graduates, participated in MASHAV’s presentation at the Ministry of Foreign Affairs’ National Cadet Course. They shared their experiences transforming academic research into practical community development strategies, helping communities worldwide achieve sustainable growth.
